Award.AwardTitle: Defining the Mechanistic Strategies of Defulfonation in the Alkanesulfonate Sulfonate Monooxygenase System

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sulfur is an essential element for all life. Bacteria play a key role in the sulfur cycle through diverse metabolic pathways. When sulfur is limited in the environment, bacteria express specific proteins to retain intracellular sulfur. The alkanesulfonate monooxygenase system provides bacteria access to an alternative sulfur source under sulfur limiting conditions. These studies will elucidate the essential role of the alkanesulfonate monooxygenase system in supplying sulfur to bacteria. The broad objective of this project is to fully establish the mechanism used by the alkanesulfonate monooxygenase system to better understand its physiological role in sulfur acquisition and the overall sulfur cycle.

An educational component of this project seeks to encourage students from underrepresented groups in the sciences to participate in research at Auburn University. The PI is collaborating with the Minority Programs Coordinator in the College of Science and Mathematics (COSAM) to participate in the Summer Bridge Program for incoming minority freshmen planning to major in sciences, mathematics, or pre-professional programs. An interactive talk on the importance of research in an undergraduate education will be presented followed by a hands-on laboratory experiment to stimulate interest in undergraduate research. The grant will provide a summer research fellowship to a minority student in COSAM for each funding year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sulfur is an essential element to maintain all of life processes. The element is used to maintain the integrity of proteins and provide them with catalytic power. While sulfur is naturally found in the environment, the form of sulfur preferred by different organisms may not be available. This is especially true for bacteria that must rely on available resources in order to survive. Bacteria have developed clever strategies that enable them to acquire sulfur from alternative resources when their preferred sulfur source is not available. These alternative sulfur sources can be products formed in the overall sulfur cycle, but can also be compounds that are generated as waste products such as those formed in the processing of fossil fuels. The overall goal of the project was to evaluate the functional and structural properties of enzymes from the alkanesulfonate monooxygenase system involved in sulfur acquisition in bacteria. Understanding the function of theses enzyme is important in understanding how bacteria survive in alternative environments and the human microbiome. The results from these findings can be modified to offer a unified mechanism for other enzymes with similar properties.

The broad objective of this project was to fully establish the mechanism of the alkanesulfonate monooxygenase system to better understand the physiological role of this system in sulfur acquisition. The primary goal of these studies was focused on how the structural properties of each enzyme defines their overall function. These studies have led to fascinating results regarding the overall process of supplying sulfur to a wide-range of bacteria during sulfur limiting conditions. We have identified several distinct structural features of this enzyme that regulate the overall function of these enzymes. Although this structural feature has been identified in a large number of proteins involved in different metabolic processes, there has been little information regarding the functional role of this structure. These findings offer valuable insight on the role of this structural property in other enzymes, which will stimulate additional research activities. In addition to the crucial research findings, the project has supported five graduate students that have expanded their scientific training in both industry and academia. There were six undergraduate students trained on this project that are continuing their education in graduate programs at esteemed graduate programs, two of which obtained graduate fellowships from the NSF. Summer fellowships were also provided for undergraduate students underrepresented in the sciences to work on this project. An ongoing outreach program was established to provide research training and develop critical thinking skills to incoming freshman pursuing degrees in science and engineering. These studies have generated exciting research findings that have expanded our research directives, and have led to innovative training for students at all levels.
